Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Ultra High Pressure Liquid Chromatograph - Mass Spectrometer for Interdisciplinary Undergraduate Research and Teaching in Chemistry and Related Fields
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) program, Professor Wendy Cory from the College of Charleston and colleagues Vijay Vulava, Marcello Forconi, Brooke Van Horn and Jennifer Fox will acquire a mass spectrometer with an ultra high pressure liquid chromatograph (UHPLC-MS). The award will enhance research training and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) studying the environmental fate of pharmaceutically active compounds; (b) quantifying relative amounts of target proteins present in wild-type and mutant yeast mitochondria; (c) determining the kinetics of hydrolysis of sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) and similar substrates by the SdsA1 enzyme; and (d) examining hydrolytically degraded co-polyesters with incorporated synthetic monomers.

A UHPLC-MS combines the physical separation capability of liquid chromatography with the mass analysis ability of mass spectrometry. The liquid chromatograph under pressure separates a mixture into its molecular components. These components flow into a mass spectrometer where they are ionized into a parent ion and fragment ions and their masses are measured. This highly sensitive technique allows the identity of the substances in a complex mixture to be determined and their structures and quantities. This instrumentation will provide faculty and students in two departments the opportunity to pursue research projects using modern, more sensitive instrumentation. It will also be used in several laboratory courses to train significant numbers of students in the use of this important analytical technique.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF-MRI research grant CHEM-1229559 was awarded to the College of Charleston, a primarily undergraduate institution (PUI) in Charleston, SC. The title of the proposed research was "Acquisition of an Ultra High Pressure Liquid Chromatograph - Mass Spectrometer for Interdisciplinary Undergraduate Research and Teaching in Chemistry and Related Fields." With this grant, a new Liquid Chromatograph - Mass Spectrometer was purchased by the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry for use in independent research projects by undergraduate students and faculty members not only in chemistry and biochemistry but also in projects related to biology and geology. 

Several research projects were conducted by students, primarily during the summers, involving this piece of equipment. These projects could not have been done without the capabilities of the UHPLC-MS, which include measuring and identifying trace amounts of compounds in complicated samples such as biological and environmental samples.

Dr. Wendy Cory and Dr. Vijay Vulava conducted research projects with students in which the behavior of pharmaceuticals in the environment was investigated. Pharmaceuticals enter our aquatic environment after human use and as a result have been found to have an effect on the aquatic environment and organisms living there. Dr. Cory's research focused on what would happen to these dissolved compounds after they were exposed to solar radiation in surface waters. It was observed that these compounds would often break down and form new related compounds as a result of photochemical reactions. Some of these compounds were determined to be of potentially greater risk than the original pharmaceuticals themselves. Dr. Vulava's students investigated the way these pharmaceuticals would potentially bind to soils, which would determine whether they would ultimately concentrate in soils or remain in the aqueous environment. A collaboration with Dr. Allison Welch led to investigations of the effects all of these compounds had on the growth and development of Southern Toad tadpoles. The UHPLC-MS made it possible for students to measure the amounts of each pharmaceutical in water samples, as well as to detect, measure, and identify new compounds forming as a result of photochemical reactions.

Other researchers using this lab instrument include biochemists looking at enzymes and how they function in the human body. The research of Dr. Jennifer Fox's lab focused on the mitochondrial electron transport chain, whose function has a broad impact on human health and is implicated in aging and Parkinson's disease. Dr. Marcello Forconi's group investigated an enzyme called SdsA1 that can break down SDS, which is found in detergents, and possibly be used in bioremediation and clean-up of the environment after chemical spills and other man-made disasters.

Dr. Brooke Van Horn and Dr. Neal Tonks both focused on investigations of potential new ways to use polymers in delivering medicine to specific targets in the body. The acquisition of the UHPLC-MS allowed them to detect and identify potential products of biodegradation that would determine the viability of such drug transport devices and the risks that might be associated with them.

This grant has allowed each of these research projects to move forward with undergraduate students conducting the research. Over one hundred students have been involved in our research programs as a result of this grant, including many from underrepresented minority groups (10-20%) and young women (60-70%). The UHPLC-MS was also used in many laboratory courses with the goal of having as many students as possible gain hands-on experience with this important, powerful laboratory tool.
